Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a text from Sam: “Did you really mean what you said earlier?” My stomach dropped. I replayed the offhand comment I’d made at lunch, realizing too late how it must have sounded. As a friend, I knew I needed to call Sam right away, to apologize and explain myself before the misunderstanding grew. But as I reached for my phone, I glanced at the clock—polls were closing soon, and I still hadn’t voted. I’d grabbed the wrong wallet this morning, and my only valid ID was at home. I could still fetch it later, but the window was closing fast.

My heart pounded. Sam deserved my full attention, but so did my civic duty. If I called now, I might miss my chance to vote. If I rushed out the door, Sam might think I didn’t care. Both roles demanded something immediate from me, and I felt torn in two, paralyzed by the weight of what I owed to my friend and to my responsibilities as a voter.
